choices.text: It is a bluish, soft cystic lesion most commonly found on the lower lip and arises from minor salivary glands
It is a neoplastic lesion typically found on the tongue and requires chemotherapy
It is a retention cyst of major salivary glands and is commonly found over the parotid duct
Observation is sufficient in most cases as mucoceles tend to resolve spontaneously without intervention

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding mucocele is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a bluish, soft cystic lesion most commonly found on the lower lip and arises from minor salivary glands

 

This option accurately summarizes the most common site (lower lip), lesion characteristics (soft, bluish), and origin (minor salivary glands).

 

A mucocele is a retention cyst that forms due to blockage or rupture of the duct of a minor salivary gland, resulting in mucus extravasation and a cyst-like swelling. Key clinical features include:

 

  • Most common site: Lower lip
  • Appearance: Soft, bluish, cystic swelling
  • Etiology: Often caused by trauma (e.g., lip biting)
  • Treatment: Surgical excision is the treatment of choice to prevent recurrence

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. It is a neoplastic lesion typically found on the tongue and requires chemotherapy: Incorrect. Mucoceles are not neoplastic and do not occur on the tongue; chemotherapy is not indicated.

 

Option C. It is a retention cyst of major salivary glands and is commonly found over the parotid duct: Incorrect. Mucoceles arise from minor, not major salivary glands; the parotid duct is unrelated to mucocele formation.

 

Option D. Observation is sufficient in most cases as mucoceles tend to resolve spontaneously without intervention: Incorrect. While some small mucoceles may temporarily regress, most require surgical excision to prevent recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucocele is a bluish, soft cystic lesion of minor salivary glands, most commonly on the lower lip, and requires surgical excision.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 223

choices.text: Start high-dose systemic corticosteroids and wait 6 months before reassessment
Begin biweekly intralesional dexamethasone with hylase, stop irritants, and start jaw-opening exercises
Proceed directly with nasolabial flap surgery for immediate relief of trismus
Prescribe antifungal mouthwash and multivitamins only and observe

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a 10-year history of betel nut chewing presents with progressive difficulty opening his mouth, burning sensation while eating spicy food, and poor oral hygiene. Examination reveals palpable fibrotic bands in the buccal mucosa and trismus. He is diagnosed with advanced oral submucous fibrosis (OSF). Conservative management has failed, and surgical intervention is planned. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management before considering surgical treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Begin biweekly intralesional dexamethasone with hylase, stop irritants, and start jaw-opening exercises

 

Best reflects the standard initial medical treatment for OSF before surgical options are considered.

 

The first-line treatment for oral submucous fibrosis, especially in the early to moderate stages, includes medical management before considering surgery:

 

  • Intralesional steroid injections (Dexamethasone 4 mg + Hylase 1500 IU):
    • Delivered biweekly for 8–10 weeks
    • Reduces inflammation and collagen deposition
    • Improves mouth opening and burning sensation
  • Avoid irritants: Areca nut, tobacco, pan masala, spicy foods
  • Correct nutritional deficiencies: Vitamins, iron
  • Jaw-opening exercises: Help reduce fibrosis-related trismus

 

Surgical treatment is reserved for advanced cases where fibrosis causes severe trismus or failure of medical therapy. Surgical options include:

 

  • Buccal mucosal release with grafts or flaps (nasolabial, tongue, palatal, radial forearm)
  • Coronoidectomy and myotomy in severe cases

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Start high-dose systemic corticosteroids and wait 6 months before reassessment: Incorrect. Systemic steroids are less effective and have more side effects than intralesional steroids, especially without local delivery.

 

Option C. Proceed directly with nasolabial flap surgery for immediate relief of trismus: Incorrect. Surgery like nasolabial flap is for advanced unresponsive cases and carries complications like scarring and staged procedures.

 

Option D. Prescribe antifungal mouthwash and multivitamins only and observe: Incorrect. While vitamins help, antifungals are not indicated unless candida is proven. Observation alone is insufficient in a symptomatic, fibrotic case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial management of OSF involves intralesional steroids with hylase, cessation of irritants, nutritional support, and jaw exercises; surgery is reserved for advanced, refractory cases.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 221–222

choices.text: Thrush presents as white patches that cannot be wiped off and is commonly seen in immunocompetent adults
Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis is most commonly seen in infants and resolves spontaneously
Thrush and hypertrophic candidiasis presents as non-wipeable white lesions
Thrush is treated with topical nystatin or clotrimazole, while hypertrophic candidiasis may require excisional surgery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding oral candidiasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thrush is treated with topical nystatin or clotrimazole, while hypertrophic candidiasis may require excisional surgery

 

Oral candidiasis (Moniliasis), caused by Candida albicans, occurs in two main forms:

 

1. Thrush:

 

  • Seen in infants, children, or immunocompromised adults (e.g., diabetes, malignancy, antibiotics, steroids, radiation)
  • Appears as white/grey patches over the oral mucosa and tongue
  • Patches can be wiped off, revealing red mucosa underneath
  • Treated with topical antifungals like nystatin or clotrimazole

 

 

2. Chronic Hypertrophic Candidiasis (Candidal Leukoplakia):

 

  • Seen mostly in adults
  • Appears as white plaques that cannot be wiped off
  • Commonly affects anterior buccal mucosa near the angle of the mouth
  • Often requires excisional surgery for treatment.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Thrush presents as white patches that cannot be wiped off and is commonly seen in immunocompetent adults: Incorrect. Thrush is wipeable and usually affects infants and immunocompromised adults, not immunocompetent ones.

 

Option B. Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis is most commonly seen in infants and resolves spontaneously: Incorrect. Chronic hypertrophic candidiasis is not common in infants and does not resolve spontaneously.

 

Option C. Thrush and hypertrophic candidiasis presents as non-wipeable white lesions: Incorrect. Thrush presents as wipeable white patches on the oral mucosa, while hypertrophic candidiasis presents as non-wipeable white lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrush responds to topical antifungals, while chronic hypertrophic candidiasis may need excisional surgery.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 218

choices.text: Reassurance and monitoring with no intervention
Mandibular nerve block to relieve referred pain
Styloid process excision via transoral or cervical approach
Tonsillectomy to decompress surrounding structures

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with persistent dull pain in the tonsillar region and upper neck, radiating to the ipsilateral ear. The pain worsens with swallowing. On examination, transoral palpation of the tonsillar fossa elicits tenderness over a bony projection. Lateral skull X-ray reveals an elongated styloid process. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Styloid process excision via transoral or cervical approach

 

  • Definitive treatment for symptomatic Eagle syndrome

 

This patient presents with classic Eagle syndrome (styalgia):

 

  • Elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament
  • Pain in tonsillar fossa, upper neck, and ear
  • Aggravated by swallowing
  • Diagnosed by:
    • Transoral palpation of elongated process in tonsillar fossa
    • Radiographic confirmation (lateral skull or AP with open mouth)

 

 

Management:

 

  • If asymptomatic → no treatment
  • If symptomatic → surgical excision of the styloid process through:
    • Transoral (less invasive, limited exposure)
    • Cervical (better visualization, more extensive)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance and monitoring with no intervention: Only appropriate in asymptomatic individuals with incidental finding of elongated styloid

 

Option B. Mandibular nerve block to relieve referred pain: Not effective in Eagle syndrome, as the pain arises from mechanical irritation of cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, X)

 

Option D. Tonsillectomy to decompress surrounding structures: Tonsils are not the source of pain; this procedure does not relieve the underlying mechanical compression

 

Educational Objective:


Eagle syndrome (styalgia) is caused by an elongated styloid process and is treated with surgical excision in symptomatic cases.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 272

choices.text: Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx
High-resolution CT scan of the paranasal sinuses
Diagnostic nasal endoscopy under general anesthesia
Trial of oral corticosteroids and saline irrigation

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought by his parents with complaints of chronic mouth breathing, snoring, and difficulty hearing. The child has a history of recurrent upper respiratory infections and poor school performance due to inattention. On physical examination, adenoid facies is noted. The physician suspects adenoid hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx
 

Reveals the size of adenoids and how much they encroach into the nasopharyngeal airway. Standard first-line imaging when endoscopy is not feasible.

 

A lateral soft tissue X-ray of the nasopharynx is a non-invasive and commonly used investigation to assess adenoid size and evaluate the degree of nasopharyngeal airway compromise, especially in uncooperative or very young children. It is a quick, accessible, and effective initial diagnostic tool.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High-resolution CT scan of the paranasal sinuses: Not first-line for adenoids. Indicated more for evaluating chronic sinusitis or anatomical deformities. Also involves unnecessary radiation for a routine case.

 

Option C. Diagnostic nasal endoscopy under general anesthesia: Flexible or rigid nasopharyngoscopy can be done in a cooperative child without anesthesia, making this option unnecessarily invasive as an initial step.

 

Option D. Trial of oral corticosteroids and saline irrigation: Mild symptoms may benefit from decongestants and antihistamines, but corticosteroids are not standard first-line therapy for adenoid hypertrophy. Moreover, this does not provide a diagnostic evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Soft tissue lateral radiograph of the nasopharynx is the initial investigation of choice for evaluating adenoid hypertrophy and nasopharyngeal airway narrowing in children.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248.

choices.text: Rathke’s pouch represents notochordal attachment to pharyngeal endoderm and can cause Thornwaldt's disease when infected
Nasopharyngeal bursa is a remnant of buccal ectoderm and may give rise to craniopharyngioma
Thornwaldt's cyst arises from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant in the adenoid mass
Rathke’s pouch lies within the adenoids and connects to the basiocciput through the pharyngeal mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding embryological remnants in the nasopharyngeal region?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thornwaldt's cyst arises from the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant in the adenoid mass 

 

Thornwaldt’s cyst is due to infection of nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant within adenoids

 

The nasopharyngeal bursa is a median epithelial-lined recess found in the adenoid region, representing the site of notochord attachment to the pharyngeal endoderm. Infection of this remnant can lead to Thornwaldt’s cyst or abscess (Thornwaldt’s disease), causing persistent postnasal discharge or crusting.

 

 

Key Concepts:

 

  • Nasopharyngeal bursa:
    • Embryological origin: Site of notochord attachment to pharyngeal endoderm
    • Location: Median epithelial-lined recess within adenoids, extending to basiocciput periosteum
    • Pathology: Infection leads to Thornwaldt’s disease (postnasal discharge, crusting, abscess)
  • Rathke’s pouch:
    • Embryological origin: Buccal ectoderm invagination, gives rise to anterior pituitary
    • Seen clinically as a dimple above adenoids
    • Pathology: May give rise to craniopharyngioma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rathke’s pouch represents notochordal attachment to pharyngeal endoderm and can cause Thornwaldt's disease when infected:  Incorrect – This confuses Rathke’s pouch with the nasopharyngeal bursa; notochordal origin is linked to nasopharyngeal bursa, not Rathke’s pouch

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal bursa is a remnant of buccal ectoderm and may give rise to craniopharyngioma: Incorrect – Craniopharyngiomas arise from Rathke’s pouch, which is from buccal ectoderm, not the nasopharyngeal bursa

 

Option D. Rathke’s pouch lies within the adenoids and connects to the basiocciput through the pharyngeal mucosa: Incorrect – This falsely assigns anatomical characteristics of nasopharyngeal bursa to Rathke’s pouch

 

Educational Objective:
 

Thornwaldt’s cyst arises from infection of the nasopharyngeal bursa, a notochordal remnant located within the adenoid mass.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 241.

choices.text: Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatoglossus and palatopharyngeus muscles at the level of the oropharynx
Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the second pharyngeal pouch and arises from the lateral wall of the nasopharynx
Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Sphenopalatine foramen opens into the nasopharynx and is formed by the maxilla and vomer bones

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pharyngeal and adjacent anatomical structures is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fossa of Rosenmüller lies posterior to torus tubarius and is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

The fossa of Rosenmüller is a recess in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, lying posterior to the torus tubarius (the bulge caused by the cartilaginous end of the Eustachian tube), and is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

 

Key anatomical facts from the content:

 

  • Adenoids: Located at the junction of roof and posterior wall of nasopharynx
  • Thornwaldt cyst/nasopharyngeal bursa: Remnant of notochord, arises from the same area as adenoids
  • Torus tubarius: Bulge due to Eustachian tube opening
  • Fossa of Rosenmüller: Posterior to torus tubarius, common site of nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Sphenopalatine foramen: Lies 1 cm posterior to end of middle turbinate, formed by palatine bone (perpendicular plate) and pterygoid part of sphenoid; it opens into pterygopalatine fossa and is the most common site for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)
  • Pterygopalatine fossa: Between maxillary sinus and pterygoid part of sphenoid; connects laterally to infratemporal fossa via pterygomaxillary fissure
  • Passavant’s ridge: Muscular ridge formed by palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor, blocks nasopharynx during swallowing
  • Palatine tonsils: Located in oropharynx between palatoglossus (anterior pillar) and palatopharyngeus (posterior pillar)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatoglossus and palatopharyngeus muscles at the level of the oropharynx: Incorrect – Passavant’s ridge is formed by palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor, not by palatoglossus

 

Option B. Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the second pharyngeal pouch and arises from the lateral wall of the nasopharynx: Incorrect – Thornwaldt cyst is a remnant of the notochord, not the second pharyngeal pouch, and arises from the posterior wall, not lateral wall

 

Option D. Sphenopalatine foramen opens into the nasopharynx and is formed by the maxilla and vomer bones: Incorrect – Sphenopalatine foramen is formed by the perpendicular plate of palatine bone and pterygoid process of sphenoid, not maxilla and vomer, and it opens into the nasal cavity, not nasopharynx

 

Educational Objective:
 

The fossa of Rosenmüller, located posterior to the torus tubarius, is the most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 254

choices.text: Start high-dose corticosteroids and observe for regression
Endoscopic surgical excision within 24–48 hours of embolization
Plan radiotherapy to the nasopharynx to achieve long-term regression
Initiate androgen-blocking therapy with flutamide to shrink the tumor

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a known diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) presents with nasal obstruction, profuse recurrent epistaxis, and left facial swelling. CT imaging shows extension of the mass into the pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae, without intracranial extension. The patient underwent successful preoperative embolization. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endoscopic surgical excision within 24–48 hours of embolization

 

This is the standard approach after embolization, particularly if tumor is accessible via endoscopy.

 

The treatment of choice for JNA is surgical excision, which should be performed within 24–48 hours after embolization to minimize bleeding before collateral blood supply develops. In this case, the tumor has extended laterally (into pterygopalatine and infratemporal fossae) without intracranial spread, making it suitable for surgical resection via endoscopic or open approaches depending on accessibility.

 

Key Concepts from the Passage:

 

  • Surgery is the definitive treatment for JNA; various approaches include transpalatine, endoscopic, transmaxillary (Le Fort I), and facial translocation depending on tumor extension.
  • Preoperative embolization reduces bleeding and should be followed by surgical removal within 24–48 hours
  • Radiotherapy is reserved for recurrent, inoperable tumors or those with intracranial extension involving the internal carotid blood supply
  • Hormonal therapy and chemotherapy have limited roles and are used in selected resistant or aggressive recurrent cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start high-dose corticosteroids and observe for regression: Corticosteroids are not effective in JNA; observation is not appropriate due to risk of hemorrhage and progression.

 

Option C. Plan radiotherapy to the nasopharynx to achieve long-term regression: Radiotherapy is not first-line. It is reserved for inoperable, recurrent, or intracranial disease, especially when blood supply is from the internal carotid system.

 

Option D. Initiate androgen-blocking therapy with flutamide to shrink the tumor: Hormonal therapy has limited efficacy and is not used as primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Surgical resection within 24–48 hours after preoperative embolization is the treatment of choice for juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma without intracranial extension.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 249

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought to the ENT clinic with complaints of recurrent sore throat, bad breath, and night-time choking episodes for the past several months. Examination reveals enlarged tonsils meeting at midline, yellowish beads on the tonsillar surface, and flushing of anterior pillars. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are palpable bilaterally. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schedule for elective tonsillectomy

 

Indicated for chronic tonsillitis with functional impairment or recurrent infections

 

The patient has classical features of chronic tonsillitis:

 

  • Recurrent sore throat
  • Halitosis due to pus in crypts
  • Choking spells at night and thick speech → suggest obstructive hypertrophy
  • On exam:
    Enlarged tonsils meeting at midline → chronic parenchymatous type
    Yellowish beads of pus → chronic follicular type
    Flushing of anterior pillars and jugulodigastric lymphadenopathy → strong indicators of chronic infection
  • According to guidelines, tonsillectomy is indicated when:
     There are recurrent infections interfering with normal function
     Tonsils cause airway obstruction, dysphagia, or speech problems

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassurance and warm saline gargles: Suitable for mild symptoms, but not in patients with recurrent infections and obstructive features

 

Option B. Start a course of antibiotics for 10 days: May help in acute exacerbations, but this child has chronic signs; surgery is the definitive treatment

 

Option D. Obtain a throat swab for bacterial culture before proceeding: Not necessary for chronic cases with clear clinical features and surgical indication

 

Educational Objective:
 

Tonsillectomy is indicated in chronic tonsillitis with recurrent infections, obstructive symptoms, and significant tonsillar hypertrophy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

choices.text: Pyriform sinus carcinoma; radiotherapy is preferred even in large tumors with nodal involvement
Pyriform sinus carcinoma; cervical lymph node metastasis is rare and late in disease course
Pyriform sinus carcinoma; laryngectomy and partial pharyngectomy with neck dissection is indicated for localized disease
Postcricoid carcinoma; surgical excision is rarely used due to anatomical inaccessibility

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents with a foreign body sensation in the throat, pricking pain during swallowing, and referred earache. Examination reveals a fixed neck mass in the upper cervical region, but no hoarseness or obvious mass in the oropharynx. Indirect laryngoscopy shows pooling of secretions in the left pyriform sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis, and which of the following statements is most accurate regarding management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyriform sinus carcinoma; laryngectomy and partial pharyngectomy with neck dissection is indicated for localized disease

 

This is standard treatment if confined to pyriform sinus without postcricoid involvement

 

This is a typical case of carcinoma of the pyriform sinus, which is the most common hypopharyngeal malignancy (60%), especially in men >40 years, often presenting late due to:

 

  • Deep location
  • Silent progression
  • Early sign: foreign body sensation, referred otalgia (via CN IX)
  • Fixed cervical lymphadenopathy is often the first clinical sign due to early lymphatic spread

 

Management:

 

  • Early-stage without nodes: Radiotherapy may suffice
  • Locally advanced but confined to pyriform sinus:
    Total laryngectomy + partial pharyngectomy
     Followed by elective/prophylactic neck dissection
    Post-op radiotherapy often given
  • If tumor extends to postcricoid:
    Total laryngopharyngectomy with reconstruction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiotherapy for large tumors with nodes: Radiotherapy alone is not sufficient in node-positive or extensive disease; surgery is standard

 

Option B. Cervical nodes rare in pyriform sinus carcinoma: Lymph node metastasis is common and early (75% at presentation)

 

Option D. Postcricoid carcinoma with rare surgery: Surgery is done, often laryngopharyngectomy, despite anatomical difficulty

 

Educational Objective:
 

Pyriform sinus carcinoma commonly presents late with early nodal spread, and localized disease is treated with laryngectomy, partial pharyngectomy, and neck dissection.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 273

choices.text: Perform endoscopic biopsy of the lesion in the outpatient setting
Plan for CT-guided excision after confirming diagnosis with nasal swab cytology
Perform carotid angiography with embolization followed by surgical resection
Start high-dose corticosteroids to reduce the vascularity of the lesion

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with recurrent, spontaneous episodes of profuse epistaxis and progressive nasal obstruction. His voice has become denasal, and he complains of hearing difficulty. On examination, a purplish lobulated mass is seen filling the nasopharynx and obstructing the choanae. Otoscopy shows a dull tympanic membrane suggestive of middle ear effusion. CT scan of the head reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perform carotid angiography with embolization followed by surgical resection
 

Correct and standard of care. Angiography identifies feeders, and embolization of external carotid feeders reduces bleeding. Surgery is ideally performed within 24–48 hours of embolization to avoid revascularization.

 

This patient has classic clinical and radiological findings of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA), a vascular tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males.
Key findings:

 

  • Profuse recurrent epistaxis
  • Nasal obstruction, denasal speech, conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction
  • Nasopharyngeal mass that should not be palpated or biopsied due to risk of severe bleeding
  • CT scan finding of Holman-Miller sign (anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus) is pathognomonic
  • Carotid angiography defines vascular supply (mostly external carotid system) and allows for pre-operative embolization to minimize bleeding

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform endoscopic biopsy of the lesion in the outpatient setting: Dangerous. Biopsy in JNA carries a high risk of life-threatening hemorrhage and should be avoided unless absolutely necessary, and only under controlled conditions with general anesthesia and full setup for bleeding control.

 

Option B. Plan for CT-guided excision after confirming diagnosis with nasal swab cytology:  Nasal swab cytology does not confirm diagnosis, and CT-guided excision without angiographic embolization risks massive intraoperative bleeding.

 

Option D. Start high-dose corticosteroids to reduce the vascularity of the lesion: Steroids are not effective in reducing vascularity of JNA. Management is surgical, preceded by embolization.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is diagnosed clinically and radiologically; biopsy is avoided, and pre-operative carotid angiography with embolization is essential before surgical resection.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 248

choices.text: The mucous membrane of the pharynx is entirely lined by stratified squamous epithelium
The pharyngeal aponeurosis is thickest inferiorly and merges with the esophageal wall
The muscular coat consists of an external layer of constrictors and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles
The buccopharyngeal fascia lies internal to the pharyngeal aponeurosis and lines the mucosal surface

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the structure of the pharyngeal wall is CORRECT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The muscular coat consists of an external layer of constrictors and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles

 

  • The muscular coat is composed of:
    • External constrictor muscles
    • Internal longitudinal muscles (stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, palatopharyngeus)

 

The pharyngeal wall is composed of four layers from inside out:

 

  1. Mucous membrane
    • Lined by ciliated columnar epithelium in the nasopharynx
    • Stratified squamous epithelium elsewhere
    • Contains numerous mucous glands
  2. Pharyngeal aponeurosis (pharyngobasilar fascia)
    • Fibrous layer beneath mucosa
    • Thick near the base of the skull, thin inferiorly
    • Fills muscle gap at skull base
  3. Muscular coat
    • External layer: 3 constrictors (superior, middle, inferior)
    • Internal layer: 3 longitudinal muscles — stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, palatopharyngeus
  4. Buccopharyngeal fascia
    • Covers external surface of muscular coat
    • Extends to buccinator anteriorly
    • Blends with pharyngeal aponeurosis above superior constrictor

 

 

(a) mucous membrane, (b) pharyngobasilar fascia, (c) muscular coat and (d) buccopharyngeal fascia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The mucous membrane of the pharynx is entirely lined by stratified squamous epithelium: Incorrect – The pharynx has ciliated columnar epithelium in the nasopharynx, and stratified squamous elsewhere — not entirely squamous.

 

Option B. The pharyngeal aponeurosis is thickest inferiorly and merges with the esophageal wall: Incorrect – The pharyngeal aponeurosis is thick superiorly, not inferiorly.

 

Option D. The buccopharyngeal fascia lies internal to the pharyngeal aponeurosis and lines the mucosal surface: Incorrect – The buccopharyngeal fascia lies on the outer surface of the muscle layer, not internal.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The pharyngeal wall has a muscular coat with an external constrictor layer and an internal layer of longitudinal muscles (stylopharyngeus, salpingopharyngeus, and palatopharyngeus).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 238

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and biopsy
Cricopharyngeal myotomy with pouch excision
Proton pump inhibitor therapy with lifestyle modification
Feeding jejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, gurgling sounds on swallowing, foul breath, and occasional regurgitation of undigested food, especially at night. He reports a chronic cough and has lost significant weight over the past few months. A barium swallow reveals a posterior midline outpouching at the level of the pharyngoesophageal junction. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricopharyngeal myotomy with pouch excision

 

Definitive treatment, especially in fit patients.

 

This patient presents with classic symptoms of a Zenker’s diverticulum (pharyngeal pouch):

 

  • Occurs in elderly patients, typically >60 years
  • Caused by herniation of pharyngeal mucosa through Killian’s dehiscence (between thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus of inferior constrictor)
  • Symptoms:
    • Dysphagia (especially after a few swallows)
    • Gurgling on swallowing
    • Regurgitation of undigested food
    • Chronic cough and aspiration risk
    • May be associated with hiatus hernia
  • Diagnosis: Barium swallow is diagnostic
  • Treatment of choice: Cricopharyngeal myotomy with pouch excision

 

In debilitated patients, endoscopic Dohlman’s procedure or CO₂ laser is preferred.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopy and biopsy: Risky; there's a risk of perforating the pouch. Not done as first-line for diagnosis.

 

Option C. PPI and lifestyle modification: Useful in GERD, not pharyngeal pouch.

 

Option D. Feeding jejunostomy with chemotherapy: This would be for malignancy or advanced esophageal cancer, not for a benign diverticulum.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Zenker’s diverticulum presents with dysphagia, regurgitation, and gurgling, and is treated by cricopharyngeal myotomy with excision of the pouch.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 275

choices.text: IV antibiotics and emergency incision and drainage
Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy
Oral steroids and observation
Immediate tracheostomy to prevent airway obstruction

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with mild dysphagia, posterior throat discomfort, and a gradually enlarging midline swelling on the posterior pharyngeal wall. He also has multiple cervical lymph nodes and a history of weight loss and low-grade fever. Cervical spine X-ray reveals destruction of C3 and C4 vertebral bodies. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incision and drainage followed by full antitubercular therapy

 

This is the standard treatment for tubercular prevertebral abscesses.

 

This is a classic presentation of a chronic retropharyngeal abscess (specifically a prevertebral abscess) due to tuberculosis:

 

  • Most commonly caused by cervical spine tuberculosis (Pott’s disease)
  • Abscess lies behind the prevertebral fascia, usually midline
  • Often has minimal symptoms like mild dysphagia and throat discomfort
  • Cervical spine X-ray is diagnostic (shows vertebral destruction)
  • May be associated with tuberculous cervical lymphadenopathy

 

Management:

 

  • Incision and drainage via:
    • Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (for low abscesses)
    • Posterior border (for high abscesses)
  • Full course of ATT (antitubercular therapy) is essential to prevent recurrence and control infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV antibiotics and emergency drainage: Suitable for acute pyogenic abscess, not tubercular. Also, ATT is essential.

 

Option C. Oral steroids and observation: Steroids may worsen TB if given alone; definitive drainage and ATT are necessary.

 

Option D. Immediate tracheostomy: Airway obstruction is not typical in chronic prevertebral TB abscess. Tracheostomy is reserved for acute airway compromise, e.g., in Ludwig’s angina or acute retropharyngeal abscess.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Chronic retropharyngeal abscess due to cervical spine tuberculosis is treated with incision and drainage followed by a full course of antitubercular therapy.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 267

choices.text: Acute membranous tonsillitis
Diphtheria
Vincent angina
Infectious mononucleosis

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with low-grade fever and a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils and soft palate. The membrane is adherent and bleeds on attempted removal. There is mild sore throat, and urine analysis reveals albuminuria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diphtheria

 

Fits all described features: slow onset, mild pain, adherent membrane, bleeding on removal, soft palate involvement, and albuminuria.

 

  • Diphtheria is classically characterized by:
    • Slow onset and mild local symptoms
    • A dirty grey adherent membrane that extends beyond the tonsils to the soft palate
    • Bleeds on removal
    • Albuminuria (due to systemic toxin effects)
    • Diagnosis confirmed by throat swab showing Corynebacterium diphtheriae

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute membranous tonsillitis:  This may appear similar but the membrane is limited to the tonsils, forms from coalesced exudates in acute follicular tonsillitis, and can usually be removed without bleeding.

 

 

Option C. Vincent angina: Usually unilateral, less fever, and membrane is removable, revealing an irregular ulcer. Fusiform bacilli and spirochetes are seen on Gram stain.

 

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis:  Typically seen in young adults, with bilaterally enlarged tonsils, prominent lymphadenopathy (especially posterior triangle), and splenomegaly. Paul–Bunnell test is positive.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Diphtheria presents with an adherent, dirty grey membrane over the tonsils and soft palate that bleeds on removal and is confirmed by detection of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 260

Stage IVA
Stage IVB
Stage IVC

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and diplopia. Imaging reveals a mass in the nasopharynx with extension into the orbit and skull base. Clinical examination shows bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy, each node less than 6 cm, with no distant metastasis. What is the correct clinical stage of this patient’s nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage IVA

 

Defined as T4 with N0, N1, or N2, M0

 

Let’s break this down using the TNM classification:

 

  • T4: Tumor with intracranial extension, orbital involvement, and skull base erosion qualifies as T4
  • N2: Bilateral cervical nodes, ≤6 cm, and above supraclavicular fossa fits N2
  • M0: No distant metastasis

 

Putting this together:
 

T4 N2 M0 → Stage IVA

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage III: Includes T1–T3 with N2 or T2b with N2, but not T4

 

Option C. Stage IVB: Requires any T with N3, not present here

 

Option D) Stage IVC: Requires M1 (distant metastases), which is not the case

 

Educational Objective:
 

T4N2M0 nasopharyngeal carcinoma is classified as Stage IVA due to intracranial and orbital involvement with bilateral lymph node metastasis and no distant spread.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 253

choices.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media with cholesteatoma
Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Glomus jugulare tumor

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with progressive left-sided hearing loss and a painless neck lump just below the angle of the mandible. He also reports intermittent nasal obstruction and occasional epistaxis. Otoscopy reveals a dull, retracted tympanic membrane. Neurological examination reveals decreased corneal reflex on the left and mild weakness of left lateral gaze. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
 

Fits all symptoms: adult with unilateral middle ear effusion, nasal obstruction, neck mass, cranial nerve involvement (CN V and VI).

 

This patient presents with classic features of NPC, including:

 

  • Unilateral serous otitis media in an adult (suggestive of eustachian tube obstruction)
  • Nasal obstruction and epistaxis
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy near the angle of the mandible
  • Cranial nerve involvement: CN V (decreased corneal reflex), CN VI (lateral rectus palsy causing diplopia)

 

These signs and symptoms are typical of NPC with skull base extension, which may involve cranial nerves V, VI, and cause Trotter’s triad (conductive hearing loss, facial pain, palatal paralysis). Cervical node metastasis is the most common presentation, occurring in up to 90% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic suppurative otitis media with cholesteatoma: While this can cause hearing loss and retracted TM, it does not explain the neck mass, epistaxis, nasal symptoms, or cranial nerve palsies.

 

Option B. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Seen in adolescent males, not a 35-year-old adult. Also presents with profuse epistaxis, not cranial neuropathies or lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Glomus jugulare tumor: Can cause lower cranial nerve palsies (IX–XI) and pulsatile tinnitus, but nasal symptoms and lymphadenopathy are not typical. Also, it's located in the jugular foramen, not nasopharynx.

 

Educational Objective:


Nasopharyngeal carcinoma commonly presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, unilateral serous otitis media, nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and cranial nerve palsies due to skull base extension.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 251

choices.text: Hoarseness and vocal cord paralysis
Otalgia and trismus
Hypothyroidism and neck swelling
Stridor and respiratory distress

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a several-month history of dysphagia, a muffled voice, and a sensation of fullness in her throat. On examination, she has a bulge in the lateral pharyngeal wall and decreased sensation in the area innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve. Imaging reveals a mass in the parapharyngeal space. Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of a parapharyngeal space lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Otalgia and trismus

 

Option B:

 

Parapharyngeal space lesions can present with referred otalgia due to shared cranial nerve innervation and trismus due to involvement of the muscles of mastication or pterygoid muscles. These symptoms, along with dysphagia and voice changes, are characteristic of parapharyngeal space involvement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hoarseness and vocal cord paralysis: Incorrect. While hoarseness and vocal cord paralysis could be caused by lesions affecting the recurrent laryngeal nerve, this nerve does not typically run through the parapharyngeal space.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism and neck swelling: Incorrect. Hypothyroidism is not a feature of parapharyngeal space lesions, and while neck swelling could be present, it is non-specific and could be associated with various conditions.

 

Option D. Stridor and respiratory distress: Incorrect. Stridor and respiratory distress are more indicative of airway compromise, which can occur with large parapharyngeal space masses but are not as specific as otalgia and trismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic clinical features of a parapharyngeal space lesion include dysphagia, a sensation of fullness in the throat, referred otalgia, and trismus, reflecting the complex anatomy and the variety of structures within or adjacent to the parapharyngeal space.

choices.text: Thyroid cartilage forms a complete ring with an anterior arch and posterior lamina
Epiglottis has a complete ring-like structure and lies anterior to the vocal cords
Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring with a broad posterior lamina and narrow anterior arch
Arytenoid cartilage forms a complete ring and articulates directly with the thyroid cartilage

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is undergoing endoscopic examination of the larynx. The surgeon identifies a laryngeal cartilage that forms a complete ring and has a broad posterior part and a narrow anterior arch. Which of the following statements correctly describes this cartilage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricoid cartilage forms a complete ring with a broad posterior lamina and narrow anterior arch

 

 

  • The cricoid cartilage is the only laryngeal cartilage that forms a complete ring.
  • Its posterior part is expanded and known as the lamina, while the anterior part is narrower and forms an arch.
  • This anatomical structure provides a critical support for the lower larynx and is important during procedures like tracheostomy and endotracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Thyroid cartilage forms a complete ring with an anterior arch and posterior lamina: Incorrect. The thyroid cartilage is open posteriorly and does not form a complete ring.
 

Option B .Epiglottis has a complete ring-like structure and lies anterior to the vocal cords: Incorrect. The epiglottis is a leaf-like structure that does not form a ring.
 

Option D. Arytenoid cartilage forms a complete ring and articulates directly with the thyroid cartilage: Incorrect. The arytenoid cartilage is paired and sits on the cricoid lamina but does not form a complete ring.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Cricoid cartilage is the only laryngeal cartilage that forms a complete ring, with a broad posterior lamina and narrow anterior arch.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: The corniculate cartilage has undergone age-related hyaline ossification
The epiglottis is composed of hyaline cartilage and commonly ossifies with age
Hyaline cartilage ossification of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages can mimic foreign bodies
Aryepiglottic fold contains hyaline cartilage, which calcifies after age 25

questions.text: A 58-year-old man undergoes a lateral neck X-ray for evaluation of dysphagia. The radiologist notes calcified shadows near the larynx, but no clinical evidence of a foreign body is found. Which of the following best explains this radiological finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyaline cartilage ossification of the thyroid and cricoid cartilages can mimic foreign bodies

 

 

 

  • Thyroid, cricoid, and most of the arytenoid cartilages are composed of hyaline cartilage, which can undergo ossification.
  • Ossification starts around age 25 in the thyroid cartilage, slightly later in the cricoid and arytenoids, and is complete by around 65 years.
  • This calcification may appear as dense shadows on X-rays, potentially being misinterpreted as foreign bodies in the esophagus or larynx.
  • In contrast, epiglottis, corniculate, cuneiform, and the tip of the arytenoid (near the corniculate) are made of elastic fibrocartilage, which does not ossify like hyaline cartilage.

 

Other Options:


Option A. The corniculate cartilage has undergone age-related hyaline ossification: Incorrect. Corniculate cartilage is elastic fibrocartilage and does not undergo ossification.
 

Option B. The epiglottis is composed of hyaline cartilage and commonly ossifies with age: Incorrect. Epiglottis is made of elastic fibrocartilage, not hyaline, and rarely ossifies.
 

Options D. Aryepiglottic fold contains hyaline cartilage, which calcifies after age 25: Incorrect. Aryepiglottic fold contains cuneiform and corniculate cartilages, which are elastic, not hyaline.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Ossification of hyaline cartilages like thyroid and cricoid can appear as calcifications on X-rays, potentially mimicking foreign bodies.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Cricotracheal membrane connecting cricoid cartilage to trachea
Cricovocal membrane forming the vocal ligament and conus elasticus
Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by internal laryngeal nerve
Aryepiglottic fold containing the cuneiform cartilage

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with sudden-onset respiratory distress after suspected inhalation of a small toy part. Imaging reveals the foreign body lodged in the subglottic region. Which of the following intrinsic laryngeal structures is most likely involved in the impaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricovocal membrane forming the vocal ligament and conus elasticus

 

 

  • The cricovocal membrane is a triangular fibroelastic structure considered an intrinsic membrane of the larynx.
  • Its upper free border stretches from the middle of the thyroid angle to the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage, forming the vocal ligament.
  • Its lower border is attached to the arch of the cricoid cartilage.
  • Together with its counterpart on the opposite side, it forms the conus elasticus, a cone-shaped membrane below the vocal cords.
  • Subglottic foreign bodies often get impacted in the conus elasticus, making it clinically significant in airway emergencies.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cricotracheal membrane connecting cricoid cartilage to trachea: Incorrect. Cricotracheal membrane is extrinsic and connects cricoid cartilage to the trachea; it’s not part of conus elasticus.

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane pierced by internal laryngeal nerve: Incorrect. Thyrohyoid membrane is extrinsic and pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve; unrelated to subglottic obstruction.

Option D. Aryepiglottic fold containing the cuneiform cartilage: Incorrect. Aryepiglottic fold is supraglottic, and not involved in subglottic foreign body impaction.

 

Educational Objective:


The cricovocal membrane forms the vocal ligament and, with its opposite side, forms the conus elasticus, where subglottic foreign bodies may get impacted.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

questions.text:
A 45-year-old patient is undergoing evaluation for voice changes. The ENT surgeon reviews the laryngeal muscle function and asks the resident to match specific laryngeal muscles to their corresponding actions on the vocal cords. Match the following muscles (List A) with their primary functions (List B):

 

List A (Laryngeal Muscles):

 

  1. Posterior cricoarytenoid
  2. Lateral cricoarytenoid
  3. Cricothyroid
  4. Vocalis

 

List B (Function):

 

  1. Abduction of vocal cords
  2. Adduction of vocal cords
  3. Tension regulation of vocal cords
  4. Pitch modulation by fine-tuning the vocal ligament

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • Posterior cricoarytenoid (1-A): The only abductor of the vocal cords, opens the glottis.
  • Lateral cricoarytenoid (2-B): Pulls vocal cords medially, thus acts as an adductor.
  • Cricothyroid (3-C): Increases tension of the vocal cords by tilting the thyroid cartilage forward.
  • Vocalis (4-D): Fine-tunes pitch by adjusting tension in segments of the vocal ligament.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intrinsic muscles of the larynx control vocal cord abduction, adduction, and tension—posterior cricoarytenoid abducts, lateral cricoarytenoid adducts, cricothyroid tenses, and vocalis fine-tunes pitch.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 283

questions.text:
A medical student is asked to classify the extrinsic muscles of the larynx based on their function and attachment. Match the following muscles (List A) with their correct functional classification (List B):

 

List A (Muscles):

 

  1. Stylopharyngeus
  2. Mylohyoid
  3. Sternothyroid
  4. Omohyoid

 

List B (Function):

 

  1. Primary elevator of larynx
  2. Secondary elevator of larynx
  3. Depressor of larynx
  4. Adductor of vocal cords

 

Which of the following is the correct matching?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-C

 

  • Stylopharyngeus (1-A): A primary elevator, directly attaches to the thyroid cartilage, elevating the larynx during swallowing.

 

 

  • Mylohyoid (2-B): A secondary elevator, attached to the hyoid bone, elevates the larynx indirectly.

 

 

  • Sternothyroid (3-C): A depressor of the larynx, pulls the thyroid cartilage downward.

 

 

  • Omohyoid (4-C): Also a depressor, pulling the hyoid bone and hence the larynx downward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Extrinsic laryngeal muscles act as elevators or depressors based on their attachment to either thyroid cartilage or hyoid bone.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 284

choices.text: Sensation above vocal cords
Sensation below vocal cords
Motor supply to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles
Tension of the vocal cords

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoing thyroid surgery sustains injury to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Which of the following is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tension of the vocal cords

 

Cricothyroid muscle, which controls tension of the vocal cords, is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Damage leads to inability to produce high-pitched sounds.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensation above vocal cords: Supplied by the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, not the external branch.

 

Option B. Sensation below vocal cords: Supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, not related to the external branch.

 

Option C. Motor supply to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles: All intrinsic muscles except cricothyroid are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords, is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg. 298

choices.text: It supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx
It arises higher in the neck than the right nerve
It has a shorter course than the right nerve
It loops around the aortic arch and has a longer intrathoracic course

questions.text: Which of the following statements best explains why the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury or paralysis than the right?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It loops around the aortic arch and has a longer intrathoracic course

 

This longer course in the mediastinum makes the left recurrent laryngeal nerve more susceptible to injury from thoracic pathologies (e.g., aortic aneurysm, mediastinal tumors).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It supplies all intrinsic muscles of the larynx: True for both recurrent laryngeal nerves, but does not explain the higher susceptibility of the left nerve.

 

Option B. It arises higher in the neck than the right nerve: Incorrect. In fact, the left arises lower, from the thorax.


Option C. It has a shorter course than the right nerve: Incorrect. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a longer course as it loops around the aortic arch in the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to paralysis due to its longer intrathoracic course, looping around the aortic arch.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 298

choices.text: Teflon injection into the vocal cord
Immediate Type I thyroplasty
Observation and voice therapy
Arytenoid adduction surgery

questions.text: A 50-year-old male underwent thyroid surgery 3 months ago. He now presents with mild hoarseness of voice but no aspiration or breathing difficulty. Flexible laryngoscopy shows a left vocal cord in paramedian position with partial compensation by the right cord. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Observation and voice therapy

 

Since many patients compensate over time and temporary paralysis may recover within 6–12 months, waiting and supportive therapy is appropriate. Gelfoam/fat injection may be considered if voice is significantly impaired during this period.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teflon injection into the vocal cord: Not preferred currently due to foreign body reaction and stiffness. It was used previously for permanent medialization.

Option B. Immediate Type I thyroplasty: Type I thyroplasty is for persistent symptoms and posterior glottic incompetence. It is not indicated immediately, especially when spontaneous recovery is possible in 6–12 months.

Option D. Arytenoid adduction surgery: Reserved for cases where posterior glottis is also incompetent and medialization is inadequate with thyroplasty alone. Not the first-line approach in early or mild unilateral paralysis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Most cases of unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis improve spontaneously and are managed conservatively for the first 6–12 months.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299

choices.text: Type I Thyroplasty
Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
Injection laryngoplasty
Recurrent laryngeal nerve reanastomosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with chronic exertional stridor following bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during thyroidectomy. Her voice remains fairly good. She refuses permanent tracheostomy and prefers an option that widens the airway through the larynx. Which of the following is the most appropriate endoscopic surgical procedure to relieve her airway obstruction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)

 

This endoscopic procedure excises soft tissue at the junction of the membranous cord and vocal process using a laser to widen the airway. It is the preferred modern approach for bilateral abductor palsy, avoiding tracheostomy.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I Thyroplasty: Incorrect. Type I thyroplasty is a medialization procedure used in unilateral vocal cord palsy to improve voice, not to relieve airway in bilateral abductor paralysis.

 

 

 

Option C. Injection laryngoplasty: Incorrect. Also used for medialization in unilateral palsy, mainly to improve voice—not suitable for opening airway in bilateral paralysis.

 

 

Option D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve reanastomosis: Incorrect. These reinnervation procedures have shown limited success and are not first-line or definitive airway-widening strategies in bilateral cases.

Educational Objective: 

 

Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation) is the preferred modern endoscopic procedure to relieve airway obstruction in bilateral abductor paralysis without the need for a permanent tracheostomy.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 300

choices.text: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy
Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
External branch of superior laryngeal nerve injury

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with persistent choking while eating, frequent bouts of coughing during swallowing, and a weak, husky voice. He has a recent history of cervical lymphadenopathy and was treated for diphtheria two months ago. Laryngoscopic examination reveals bilateral flaccid vocal cords and loss of protective airway reflexes. Which of the following best explains the clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy

 

Paralysis of both cricothyroid muscles leads to weak and husky voice. Bilateral sensory loss above vocal cords results in absence of protective reflexes, leading to aspiration of food and secretions, cough, and choking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: Incorrect. This results in bilateral abductor paralysis with stridor and airway obstruction but voice is usually good. Aspiration is not a predominant symptom unless glottic incompetence is severe.

 

Option C. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: Incorrect. Usually asymptomatic or mild hoarseness without aspiration. Does not cause bilateral symptoms like choking on both sides.

 

Option D. External branch of superior laryngeal nerve injury: Incorrect. Involves only the motor function to cricothyroid muscle on one side, leading to inability to raise pitch. No sensory deficit or aspiration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy causes weak voice and aspiration due to loss of cricothyroid function and bilateral sensory loss above the glottis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 300

choices.text: Narrow cricothyroid space and flat thyroid cartilage
Subglottic narrowing due to smaller diameter of cricoid cartilage
High position of the larynx allowing epiglottis to meet the soft palate
Long and firm laryngeal cartilages resistant to collapse

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with inspiratory stridor and difficulty feeding. On examination, the child shows signs of upper airway obstruction. Which of the following anatomical features of the infant larynx is most likely contributing to the simultaneous occurrence of stridor and feeding difficulty?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subglottic narrowing due to smaller diameter of cricoid cartilage

 

In infants, the subglottis is the narrowest part of the airway, as the cricoid cartilage is smaller than the glottis. This contributes to a higher risk of airway obstruction during inflammation or edema, leading to stridor and respiratory distress.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Narrow cricothyroid space and flat thyroid cartilage: This affects tracheostomy access and surgical landmarks, but does not explain stridor or feeding issues.

 

Option C. High position of the larynx allowing epiglottis to meet the soft palate: This anatomical arrangement helps feeding and breathing simultaneously, and prevents aspiration, not causes it.

 

Option D. Long and firm laryngeal cartilages resistant to collapse: In fact, infant cartilages are soft and prone to collapse, which increases the risk of obstruction—not the opposite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subglottis is the narrowest part of the infant airway due to the smaller diameter of the cricoid cartilage, making it a common site for airway obstruction and stridor.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 286

choices.text: Strangulation
Penetrating gunshot wound
Blunt trauma from steering wheel impact
Kick to the neck during physical assault

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle accident. He has hoarseness of voice, anterior neck pain, and subcutaneous emphysema. Imaging reveals disruption in the laryngotracheal framework. Which of the following is the most common cause of such laryngotracheal trauma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blunt trauma from steering wheel impact

 

The most common cause of laryngotracheal trauma is blunt trauma to the neck, particularly in automobile accidents, where the neck strikes the steering wheel or dashboard.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strangulation: Less common cause. May cause laryngeal fracture or soft tissue edema, but it's not the most frequent.

 

Option B. Penetrating gunshot wound: Penetrating injuries are less common than blunt trauma in civilian settings.

 

Option D. Kick to the neck during physical assault: Also a recognized cause, but less frequent compared to motor vehicle accidents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blunt trauma from automobile accidents, especially when the neck strikes the steering wheel, is the most common cause of laryngotracheal injury.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 287

Children are more prone to laryngeal fractures due to soft cartilage
Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may occur due to cricothyroid joint dislocation
Thyroid cartilage fractures do not affect false vocal cords

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents after a road traffic accident with hoarseness, subcutaneous emphysema in the neck, and inspiratory stridor. On examination, there is tenderness over the thyroid cartilage and crepitus on palpation. Which of the following is most likely true regarding laryngotracheal trauma in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury may occur due to cricothyroid joint dislocation

 

The recurrent laryngeal nerve passes just behind the cricothyroid joint. Dislocation at this joint can injure the nerve, causing vocal cord paralysis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dislocation of cricoarytenoid joint has no impact on vocal cord function: Incorrect. Cricoarytenoid joint dislocation can cause arytenoid displacement, leading to hoarseness, voice change, or airway obstruction due to impaired cord movement.

 

Option B. Children are more prone to laryngeal fractures due to soft cartilage: Incorrect. Children are less prone because their laryngeal cartilages are more resilient and less calcified than adults.

 

Option D. Thyroid cartilage fractures do not affect false vocal cords: Incorrect. Fracture of upper thyroid cartilage may avulse epiglottis and false cords.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dislocation of the cricothyroid joint in laryngeal trauma may injure the recurrent laryngeal nerve, leading to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 287

Laryngotracheal trauma

Peritonsillar abscess

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident with hoarseness, painful swallowing, and difficulty breathing. On examination, there is tenderness over the anterior neck, flattening of the thyroid prominence, and palpable subcutaneous crepitus that increases with coughing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laryngotracheal trauma

 

Key features such as hoarseness, odynophagia (painful swallowing), subcutaneous emphysema, and loss of thyroid prominence contour suggest trauma to the larynx or trachea. Flattened thyroid prominence and crepitus between cartilages are classic signs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiglottitis: Incorrect. Typically presents with drooling, muffled voice, high fever, and stridor in a child or adult. Subcutaneous emphysema and palpable fractures are not features.

 

 

Option C. Retropharyngeal abscess: Incorrect. Common in children, presents with fever, neck stiffness, dysphagia, and bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall—but not crepitus or cartilage fractures.

 

 

Option D. Peritonsillar abscess: Incorrect. Characterized by unilateral sore throat, uvular deviation, trismus, and muffled voice—does not cause subcutaneous emphysema or thyroid cartilage flattening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngotracheal trauma presents with hoarseness, painful swallowing, subcutaneous emphysema, and altered neck contour due to cartilage displacement or fracture.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 287

choices.text: Immediate open reduction and plating of thyroid cartilage fracture
Endotracheal intubation followed by conservative management
Surgical repair with open reduction, cartilage wiring, and mucosal repair within 3–5 days
Observation only, as the tracheostomy is already done

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents 24 hours after sustaining blunt trauma to the neck in a bike accident. He has hoarseness, subcutaneous emphysema, and CT shows a displaced fracture of the thyroid cartilage with mucosal tear. He is breathing comfortably via tracheostomy. What is the most appropriate surgical approach at this stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Surgical repair with open reduction, cartilage wiring, and mucosal repair within 3–5 days

 

This is the standard timing and protocol for operative repair: reduce cartilage fractures, repair mucosa, stabilize with wires or miniplates, and consider internal splinting if needed.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate open reduction and plating of thyroid cartilage fracture: Incorrect. Immediate repair may be complicated by edema; ideal timing is 3–5 days after injury once swelling reduces.

 

Option B. Endotracheal intubation followed by conservative management: Incorrect. Intubation is not preferred in laryngeal trauma due to risk of worsening injury. Tracheostomy is safer and already done here.

 

Option D. Observation only, as the tracheostomy is already done: Incorrect. Without definitive repair, long-term sequelae like stenosis or poor voice outcomes may occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Open surgical repair of laryngeal trauma is ideally done within 3–5 days and includes cartilage reduction, mucosal repair, and internal stenting when needed.

 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 288

choices.text: Immediate tracheostomy
Start oral azithromycin and discharge
Administer humidified air, steroids, and racemic adrenaline
Perform bronchoscopy to remove secretions

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with a barking cough, hoarseness, stridor, and fever. He is diagnosed with acute laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer humidified air, steroids, and racemic adrenaline

 

This is the standard initial approach. Humidification loosens secretions, steroids reduce laryngeal oedema, and racemic adrenaline offers rapid relief of stridor by vasoconstriction of airway mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate tracheostomy: Incorrect. Tracheostomy is reserved for severe airway obstruction not responding to medical management, especially if intubation is needed >72 hours.

 

Option B. Start oral azithromycin and discharge: Incorrect. Croup often requires hospitalization due to risk of respiratory distress; azithromycin is not first-line, and discharge at this stage is unsafe.

 

Option D. Perform bronchoscopy to remove secretions: Incorrect. Not indicated in croup and may worsen symptoms. It is reserved for suspected foreign body or thick pseudomembrane obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Initial treatment of croup includes humidified air, systemic steroids, and nebulized racemic adrenaline to relieve airway obstruction and inflammation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 291

choices.text: Vocal cord carcinoma
Chronic hyperplastic laryngitis
Acute laryngitis
Reinke’s edema

questions.text: A 45-year-old male chronic smoker and industrial worker presents with long-standing hoarseness, frequent throat clearing, and vocal fatigue. Laryngoscopic examination reveals dusky red, thickened, and nodular vocal cords with impaired mobility. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic hyperplastic laryngitis

 

 

This condition occurs due to prolonged irritation (smoking, vocal abuse, pollution) and presents with hoarseness, throat clearing, and vocal fatigue. Laryngoscopy shows thickened, dusky red, nodular cords with impaired mobility due to mucosal infiltration or joint stiffness. It is more common in males (8:1) in the 30–50 years age group.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vocal cord carcinoma: Carcinoma presents with progressive hoarseness and may show unilateral mass or ulceration. Bilateral symmetrical thickening favors a benign inflammatory cause.

 

 

Option C. Acute laryngitis: Presents with sudden onset hoarseness and typically shows erythema and edema but not nodular changes or impaired mobility seen in chronic hyperplastic forms.

 

 

Option D. Reinke’s edema: This is a localized form of chronic laryngitis with gelatinous swelling in Reinke’s space and is more commonly bilateral and symmetrical, but typically causes fusiform swelling of cords—not the nodular appearance described here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic hyperplastic laryngitis presents with hoarseness, thickened and nodular cords, and impaired mobility, especially in male smokers exposed to irritants.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 292

choices.text: Increased subglottic pressure
Use of ventricular bands for phonation
Hyperadduction of vocal cords
Vocal cord paralysis

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a retired drama teacher and chronic smoker, presents with hoarseness and a low-pitched, rough voice for several months. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals bilateral pale fusiform swellings of the vocal cords with overhanging ventricular bands. Which of the following best explains his altered voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Use of ventricular bands for phonation

 

In Reinke’s edema, the true cords are edematous and cannot vibrate efficiently. Patients compensate by using false cords (ventricular bands) for phonation, resulting in a rough, low-pitched voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased subglottic pressure: While it may affect voice dynamics, it is not the primary cause of the hoarseness in Reinke’s edema.

 

Option C. Hyperadduction of vocal cords: Seen in functional voice disorders, not typical of Reinke’s edema.

 

Option D. Vocal cord paralysis: Leads to breathy or weak voice, not low-pitched hoarseness with fusiform swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Reinke’s edema, patients develop hoarseness due to use of ventricular bands for phonation, as the edematous vocal cords cannot vibrate effectively.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 292

choices.text: Paraglottic space
Pre-epiglottic space
Reinke’s space
Infraglottic space

questions.text: A 45-year-old female smoker presents with chronic hoarseness and low-pitched voice. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals bilateral fusiform swelling of the membranous vocal cords. Biopsy shows edematous changes without malignancy. The swelling is most likely due to edema in which of the following anatomical spaces?
questions.solution:
Ans C) Reinke’s space

 

 

  • Reinke’s space is a potential space located just beneath the epithelium of  the vocal cords, within the superficial layer of the lamina propria.
  • It contains scanty connective tissue and is crucial for vocal cord vibration.
  • It is bounded:
    • Superiorly and inferiorly by arcuate lines
    • Anteriorly by the anterior commissure
    • Posteriorly by the vocal process of the arytenoid cartilage
  • Edema in this space, commonly seen in smokers or voice overuse, leads to Reinke’s edema, presenting as fusiform swelling of the membranous cords and hoarseness.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Paraglottic space: Lies lateral to the ventricle, not beneath the vocal cord epithelium.

 

 

Option B. Pre-epiglottic space: Lies anterior to the epiglottis and is not related to vocal cord movement.

 

 

Option D. Infraglottic space: Lies below the glottis; not involved in Reinke’s edema.

 

Educational Objective:


Reinke’s edema is fusiform swelling of the membranous vocal cords due to fluid accumulation in Reinke’s space beneath the vocal cord epithelium.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 285

choices.text: Bilateral vocal cord decortication in the same sitting
Unilateral decortication followed by contralateral decortication after a few weeks
Botulinum toxin injection to the thyroarytenoid muscle
Cordectomy with laser

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a long history of voice abuse and smoking presents with gradually progressive hoarseness. Indirect laryngoscopy reveals bilateral fusiform, translucent swellings over the membranous vocal cords consistent with Reinke’s edema. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unilateral decortication followed by contralateral decortication after a few weeks

 

This is the standard surgical treatment for Reinke’s edema. The procedure involves removing a strip of edematous mucosa (decortication). It is done one side at a time to preserve airway and voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral vocal cord decortication in the same sitting: Can lead to airway compromise and poor voice outcome. Not recommended.

 

Option C. Botulinum toxin injection to the thyroarytenoid muscle : Used in spasmodic dysphonia, not Reinke’s edema.

 

Option D. Cordectomy with laser:  Too aggressive for benign lesions like Reinke’s edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinke’s edema is treated surgically by staged unilateral decortication of the vocal cords to remove edematous mucosa while preserving voice and airway.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 293

choices.text: The larynx ends at the level of the upper border of C7 vertebra
Laryngeal crepitus is a pathological finding and suggests cartilage inflammation
The larynx moves only vertically during phonation and swallowing
The larynx lies opposite the third to sixth cervical vertebrae and ends at the lower border of C6

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing neck palpation as part of a general ENT examination. During side-to-side manipulation of the laryngeal framework, the examiner notes a characteristic grating sensation. Which of the following statements about the anatomical position and mobility of the larynx is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D)The larynx lies opposite the third to sixth cervical vertebrae and ends at the lower border of C6

 

 

  • The larynx lies in front of the hypopharynx and extends from the level of the third to sixth cervical vertebrae, ending at the lower border of C6 in adults.
  • It moves vertically and in anteroposterior direction during phonation and swallowing.
  • The larynx can also be passively moved from side to side, producing a characteristic grating sensation known as laryngeal crepitus, which is a normal finding.

 

Other Options:


Option A. The larynx ends at the level of the upper border of C7 vertebra: Incorrect. The larynx ends at the lower border of C6, not C7.

 

Option B.Laryngeal crepitus is a pathological finding and suggests cartilage inflammation: Incorrect. Laryngeal crepitus is a normal physiological phenomenon, not pathological.

 

Option C. The larynx moves only vertically during phonation and swallowing: Incorrect. The larynx moves both vertically and anteroposteriorly, not just vertically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The larynx lies opposite C3–C6 vertebrae and ends at the lower border of C6, exhibiting vertical, anteroposterior, and passive side-to-side movements including normal laryngeal crepitus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 282

choices.text: Carcinoma of the right lung apex
Thyroid surgery history
Bronchogenic carcinoma
Cervical lymphadenopathy on the right side

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker presents with hoarseness of voice for 2 months. On flexible laryngoscopy, the left vocal cord is found in the paramedian position and immobile. Which of the following conditions must be ruled out first in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchogenic carcinoma

 

The left RLN loops around the arch of aorta and has a longer intrathoracic course, making it more susceptible to compression by bronchogenic carcinoma, especially from the left side of the mediastinum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoma of the right lung apex: This is a known cause of right RLN palsy, not left. The right RLN loops around the subclavian artery and is more superficial.

 

Option B. Thyroid surgery history: A relevant cause but usually bilateral or unilateral depending on side. In this question, smoking and mediastinal involvement point toward a pulmonary cause as first priority.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy on the right side: Could cause right RLN paralysis but does not explain isolated left vocal cord paralysis in this clinical context.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Left recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis in a smoker mandates ruling out bronchogenic carcinoma due to its long intrathoracic course.
 

Ref: P.L. Dhingra, Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, pg 299
